awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: Unleashing the petrogenetic potential of sanidine using a combined compositional, experimental, and 3D textural approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Hannah Shamloo has been granted an NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out research and educational plans at Oregon State University alongside mentor, Professor Adam Kent. This investigation will examine the processes that produce some of the largest volcanic eruptions known, through the study of minerals present in erupted magmas. The tool developed will help to accurately and quantitively resolve the many processes recorded in zoned minerals that lead to large eruptions. The information for relating magmatic/volcanic processes obtained from individual Barium (Ba) zoning in minerals is critical to the real-time volcano monitoring efforts of future eruptions. This study will consist of three components, (1) quantifying chemical characteristics of natural zoned sanidine from supervolcanoes, (2) perform novel 3D textural characterization of Ba zoning in sanidine, and (3) conduct a series of experiments under relevant conditions to shallow and evolved magmatic systems to constrain the behavior of Ba and other trace elements in sanidine. Additionally, the education plan will entail research opportunities for undergraduates related to this project, teaching opportunities with a focus on minorities in STEM, and outreach via social media.

This investigation will better resolve large-scale processes recorded in zoned minerals including pluton formation, initiation of volcanic eruptions, and formation of continental crust. Although the zoning of Ba in sanidine and other alkali-feldspar has been widely documented since at least the 1970’s, its use as a quantitative tool is severely limited by a lack of fundamental data, and as a result, hypotheses based on Ba zoning are often difficult to test. This study will couple in-situ major- and trace-element characterization of natural zoned sanidine from a variety of supervolcanoes using laser ablation ICP-MS and electron microprobe, with 3D textural characterization of Ba zoning using high-resolution X-ray microtomography. Additionally, a series of experiments will be performed under the relevant conditions to shallow and evolved magmatic systems using cold-seal pressure vessels and non-end-loaded piston cylinders to quantify the partitioning behavior of Ba in sanidine and silicic melt. This investigation will also develop a novel technique to study chemical zoning in crystals in 3D rather than the traditional 2D approach often used in petrology that can lead to additional uncertainty. Broader impacts include research opportunities for undergraduate students that will focus on recruiting members of unrepresented minorities in STEM majors. This project received co-funding from the Petrology and Geochemistry program in the division of Earth Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the processes that occur in a magma chamber prior to an eruption is vital information for understanding how and when a volcano will erupt. The purpose of this project was to connect these data with active monitoring techniques at a given volcano to improve eruption response. This was specifically done through a multidisciplinary approach including studying the geochemistry of naturally erupted materials (i.e., minerals and glass in lava and tephra), conducting experiments in a lab that simulate processes that occur in a magma chamber, and compiling existing literature to assess the current understanding of “eruptibility” of magma. The three main scientific objectives and outcomes from this project are outlined below. In addition, the project’s broader impacts are also outlined.

 

Objective 1: Minerals that crystallize in a magma chamber often preserve chemical zones (akin to tree rings) which represent changes in magmatic conditions that relate to pre-eruptive processes (e.g., heating, magma ascent, magma mixing). Objective 1 was to determine what controls elemental zoning in sanidine–a mineral common in rhyolite, which is a magma composition high in silica that often leads to explosive and therefore dangerous eruptions. This objective was addressed by measuring the concentration of trace elements in feldspar and co-existing glass in naturally erupted rhyolite at a variety of volcanic centers around the world. In addition, a series of cold-seal pressure vessel experiments that simulate the magmatic conditions relevant to rhyolite were conducted to address what controls partitioning behavior, in other words, what magmatic processes are represented by the chemical zoning preserved in feldspar in rhyolites?

Outcome 1: Results from studying natural samples as well as experimental samples both showed there is a wide variability of partition coefficients in trace elements (such as Ba, Sr, Mg) in sanidine and rhyolite. Additionally, temperature and pressure do not appear to control partitioning as previously suggested by existing literature, however more experiments need to be conducted to confirm this observation. Generally, these results imply that zoning in sanidine in rhyolites may be controlled by processes not directly related to heating (temperature) or ascent (pressure), rather changes in magma composition itself.  Therefore, every magmatic system may have a unique partitioning system which needs to be determined when interpreting petrologic models for a given volcano.

 

Objective 2: Volcanoes often erupt material that show evidence of magma heterogeneity in the storage system prior to eruption. For example, banded pumice represents different magma types that interact or “mingle” in the volcanic conduit upon ascent and eruption. This objective used diffusion chronometry across boundaries in banded pumice in order to address 1) What is the timing of magma mingling in the conduit upon eruption, and 2) Do the calculated timescales vary depending on which magma types are involved in mingling?

Outcome 2: Banded pumice from the Rattlesnake Tuff from eastern Oregon was used for this objective since they preserve at least five unique rhyolite compositions indicative of five magmas interacting in the conduit upon eruption. Timescales using diffusion chronometry indicate magma mingling-to-eruption on the order of minutes to hours. More specifically, higher viscosity magmas have longer ascent times, and lower viscosity magmas have shorter ascent times. This study is the first of its kind and provides the timing of magma ascent through the conduit to the surface – which can be valuable in future eruption response.

 

Objective 3: The eruptibility of magma is strongly controlled by its viscosity, which in turn is strongly controlled by the proportion of crystals to melt. This objective compiled nearly 1000 samples of erupted material available in the literature to assess the role crystallinity plays in eruptions for a variety of tectonic settings and eruptive styles.

Outcome 3: The data show a fundamental threshold between eruptible and non-eruptible magmas near 60 vol.% crystals, with dome eruptions as an exception. In addition, there is a significant relationship between SiO2 and crystallinity which agrees with previous studies. Lastly, the data suggests that both liquid/melt viscosity and crystallinity both play important roles to effective viscosity and therefore, eruptibility.

 

This project relates the timescales of magmatic/volcanic processes inferred from chemical zoning and the rock record to real-time volcano monitoring efforts of future eruptions in concert with monitoring efforts. In addition, this work promoted the professional trajectory of an early-career, female, and Mexican-Iranian scientist. She used this momentum to mentor other female and/or marginalized undergraduate students in STEM. Specifically, she has provided unique research opportunities for students who are female, members of LGBTQ+, and/or Hispanic, which have resulted in student-authored presentations at national conferences. This project also provided the opportunity for outreach at the K-12 level, including the creation of educational content for students in science classes in public schools in the US. In general, this fellowship has broadened the participation of underrepresented groups in earth science.
